General.text:
Type: Immune Globulin
Routes of Administration: IM, IV
Common Trade Names: RhoGAM, WinRho

1st_Trimester_(<12weeks)_Vaginal_Bleedin.text:
Abortion or pregnancy loss (managed medically or surgically), ACOG now recommends
no
routine Rh testing or Rho(D) immune globulin prophylaxis.
[1]
Exceptions may include
trauma
and
ectopic
(because the dataset does not include that population and the amount of fetomaternal hemorrhage and risk of alloimmunization is unknown)
Dose is 50 microgm IM
[2]
There is no harm in giving the standard 300 microgram dose, which is more readily available

2nd_&_3rd_Trimester_Vaginal_Bleeding.text:
300 microgm IM once and send Kleihauer-Betke test
Within 72hrs give additional 300 microgm/15 ml Rh-positive blood

300 microgm IM once and send Kleihauer-Betke test
Within 72hrs give additional 300 microgm/15 ml Rh-positive blood

Special_Populations.text:
Pregnancy Rating
: C
Animal studies have not been conducted, though available evidence suggest that administration of RhIG during pregnancy does not harm fetus
[3]
Lactation risk
:
Caution advised while breastfeeding, however no adverse events observed
Renal Dosing
No dosage adjustments
Hepatic Dosing
No dosage adjustments

Indications.text:
For
risk
of fetal maternal hemorrhage, such as blunt abdominal trauma
Risk = >4-12wks
Duration effect: 12wks
Also given to Rh- male trauma patients who receive O+ blood to prevent future reaction with O+ transfusions
[4]

Contraindications.text:
Allergy to class/drug
Prior sensitization of mother
Known Rh-negative father
Known Rh-negative fetus (from cord blood)

Serious.text:
Anaphylaxis
Viral transmission risk
Acute intravascular hemolysis in patients with
ITP
Acute transfusion reaction

Common.text:
Fever
Injection site reaction
Headache
Myalgias
Fatigue

Acute transfusion reaction

Pharmacology.text:
Half-life: Approximately 30 days
Metabolism: Unknown
Excretion: Unknown
Mechanism of Action:
Exact mechanism unknown
Prevents isoimmunization by suppressing immune response by Rh negative individuals against Rh positive blood cells
